utterances: And I think for a long time economists weren't even sure that bubbles exist.
Now, I think there's a growing consensus that they do and a growing understanding that we need to actually understand what creates them and how to deflate them uncatastrophically.
Drake Bennett is a staff writer for the Boston Globe.
Thank you.
Thanks a lot.
(Soundbite of song, ""Music"")
And now it's time for our staff song pick of the week.
Jazz Fest in New Orleans isn't just about jazz.
It's about music from many different genres and places.
One of the gems at this year's Jazz Fest was the Congo Square Stage.
This is where NEWS & NOTES drive engineer Sherene Strausberg got to hear her pick of the week, ""Maimouna"" by West African musician Ba Cissoko.
(Soundbite of song, ""Maimouna"")
(Singing) (Foreign language spoken)
Again, that was ""Maimouna"" by Ba Cissoko, and it's out staff song pick of the week.
NEWS & NOTES drive engineer Sherene Strausberg joins me now to tell us why.
Sherene, welcome to the other side of the soundboard.
Thank you.
It's good to be here.
It's really cool.
So tell me about your trip down to New Orleans.
It was amazing.
It was my second trip to New Orleans, first time Jazz Fest.
I went there with my boyfriend.
He'd been before, but my first Jazz Fest, and definitely not my last after this experience.
(Soundbite of song, ""Maimouna"")
(Singing) (Foreign language spoken)
Who is Ba Cissoko?
He is a West African, Ghanaian musician, and it's him and three other musicians.
They're just really great in terms of really using a very ethnic sound but combining it with Western instruments and a Western sound.
(Soundbite of song, ""Maimouna"")
So what do you like so much, specifically?
You mentioned the West meets the West.
The West of the world meets the West of Africa.
How does that play out?
I poll very well in the 3-to-6 demographic.
(LAUGHTER)
You do day drinking on your show.
Yes.
I should clarify exactly what that means because it may - sounds like I...
They also like the idea of Obama, symbolically, being - just the symbol - being the guy who has got the nomination, and maybe the president.
Although it was interesting that the poll showed that in two of the countries in the poll, United States and Jordan, McCain polled better than Obama.
I thought that was interesting, and I can't figure it out what was going on there.
But in any case, the image is still bad, but it is improving, and mostly it's hope, people think that something will change, and they are tired of what exist, and they want something new.
Does it surprise you, Ron, that the level of interest in America, particularly during this election cycle, is so high around the world?
It doesn't surprise me.

I think that, again, for having had a woman and an African-American gentleman vie for the democratic nomination, and then having Senator McCain as the Republican Nominee, I think people around the world are focused on how might Senator Obama or Senator McCain change the direction of the course of the United States, how would either of those two gentlemen impact their particular nation.
So it doesn't surprise me.
I'm always amazed when I travel around the country or travel to different countries, of how closely people watch our country in general for culture.

But it is very, very interesting to know that they're actually tuning in for political, rather than cultural notion of, hey, something is going on in the United States that we need to pay attention to.
You know, to follow that point, Ron, one interesting note from the survey was that 83 percent of people in Japan said that they were following the U.S.
election news very closely.
That's three percent more than here in the United States.
That surprise you, Mary?
Well, I couldn't tell, really, I thought that was great.

But they didn't compare it with the cycle of previous elections and go back far enough for me to tell whether it was that different, although I assume that it is, from everything else that I have heard.
They, the country, countries are right to pay attention to what goes on here.
We still are the greatest power with the most influence in the world.
And part of what goes on with our elections is not just politics, especially this time, it is also culture.
It's cultural, a phenomenon is sweeping the nation, there is some kind of transformation.
And Obama is hot, and you had Clinton as a woman, and there are all these symbols going on at the same time, that so it not just pure politics, and pure rationality about one's interests.
But they need to pay attention, and it was good that they are.
We are going to move on to another topic, but before we do, there is one more question, I want to put it to you, Mary.
And it comes from another Pew survey out this week that I thought it was pretty interesting.
It asked Americans, in this case, were they concerned about our nation's global image, and the answer was resoundingly yes, they are concerned.
Republicans and Democrats saw it as a major problem during the election cycle, the GOP less so, but still, that is a concern in an election year, isn't it?
Yes.
One thing is just not being liked.
I mean, you hate to go places and find out that people just don't like you, or your country, and your leaders.
And also, you worry about policy, you worry about danger to you if people think that your interests are so much different from theirs, so that you're some kind of evil influence in the world.
Nobody likes that, and that puts us in a very dangerous position.
So it is time for a change, and Americans should be worried about our image abroad.
Ron, presumptive Democratic nominee Barack Obama says he plans to visit Iraq and Afghanistan before the fall election.
While in Michigan this week, he reiterated his intentions to pull troops out as soon as he becomes president.
But he also says something else.
He says that he is concerned that President Bush will make some sort of binding armed forces agreement with Iraq right before he leaves office.
Do you think this is likely to happen?
I honestly don't know what Senator Obama is talking about.
I'm pleased that he has decided to visit the region.

He has been giving a lot of rhetorical flourishes to his speeches of late, saying that the United States went the wrong way with the war in Iraq, that we diverted our attention from what was going on in Afghanistan.

So I'm pleased that he will actually return to the region to talk to our men and women in uniform who are waging and winning this war on terrorism, and getting their perspective, rather than, you know, touching up his rhetorical flourishes and ruffles, if you will.
But at the same time, the Commander-in-Chief of the United States will remain George W.

Bush until next January, and it is rather presumptuous, I think, of the junior Senator from Illinois to discuss what the Commander-in-Chief's options may or may not be, be they with bilateral agreements between two countries, or working out specific arrangements with the United Nations or other world bodies.
So it is presumptuous at this juncture to talk about what the Commander-in-Chief may or may not do for military options that are available to our men and women in uniform.
But again, to wrap up, I'm pleased that Senator Obama is going to the region.
Either Senator Obama or Senator McCain will be the next Commander-in-Chief, and they need to see firsthand how the policies will affect our people in uniform.
I'm going to put a two-parter to you, Mary, and give you an opportunity to speak briefly about the issue of Barack going to Iraq.
But the major question I want to put to you is this.
In other news it was reported that Senator Hillary Clinton will have a fundraiser with some of her top contributors who seem to be frustrated with Obama's campaign.
Apparently many of Clinton's top donors have complained that Obama has not reached out to them.
So my two-parter is, really briefly on Iraq, and secondly, who is supposed to woo whom?
Clinton or Obamas?
On Iraq, I think that it's old news that we were lied to and misled and went into Iraq for the wrong reasons.
That's old news, that's very old news.
I think everybody in America has figured that out by this time.
The new news is, what do we do now?

And so he needs to go so that he will modify if need be his plans if he becomes president, and maybe some of the rhetoric leading up to it that fits with conditions on the ground now, as opposed to whatever happened back then.

As far as who is supposed to woo whom, I think that the Obama campaign, if it needs the money - and I don't know how much money they've got - needs to woo the Clinton donors in order to get their money.
And if they don't need their money then that's fine.
They can go ahead without it.
And Hillary Clinton, I think, should do everything she can to establish a record that she's tried to be helpful.
And so far she has and I think she will continue to do that.
Please clarify.
Clarify.
(SOUNDBITE OF APPLAUSE)
But it's up to the Obama - I've heard some rumblings too from people around the country, even some of them who had supported Obama saying that they are not reaching out to them now.
That's been happening from some of the pastors in the black community who are complaining about that.

But in any case, I think it's up to the Obama campaign, if he wants to bring together, heal the party and if he needs the money to reach out, and that Clinton should help and I think she is doing that.
Let's switch gears entirely in the last minute or so that we have.
Ron, I want to come to you on this, because Iowa, as we all know, has been hit very hard with storms and flooding.
Forty thousand people or more have been displaced in Iowa and a few other states by two weeks of flooding.
Associated Press giving some numbers.
Twenty four people have died.
Another 148 injured since June 6, and there could be more trouble on the way.
Some are making a comparison in the Midwest between this and Katrina.
What do you say to that, Ron?
They are two entirely different situations.
The city of New Orleans was destroyed by an act of God through a category four hurricane when the levees in New Orleans had been built to sustain a category three.

I think that there was insufficient planning at all levels of government to deal with Katrina, but I have been very encouraged by the state and local response in Illinois and in the upper Midwest to confront this tragedy.
And it's one thing that this is a non-political non-partisan issue.
Those who need water, who need help, who need assistance should get it and I'm pleased that the government at all levels has been responding very, very swiftly to confront these floods.
There's another difference in not as many people have, as far we know, have died in this thing.
Thank goodness that they haven't, but they haven't.
Some of the conditions are horrendous and I love Iowa and in particular the University of Iowa and my friends out there and I've walked that whole campus, and I hope that they don't get too flooded.
Cedar Rapids.
The poor people who live down in the low lands are the ones that you see in the shelters.
Are the ones who have been flooded out.
The people who are wealthier live on the hill.
So I think that there are some similarities.
I don't see the same kind of incompetence, at least it's not apparent yet.
We don't have a Brownie who has done a heck of a job yet.
Well, let's talk about Governor Blanco and Mayor Nagins.
So we don't know that.
But there are some comparisons.
We're going to stop it and we're going to bring it to a close.
We've run out of time you guys.
I've got to stop it right here, Mary and Ron, appreciate it.
Mary Frances Berry, professor of history at the University of Pennsylvania.
Also the former chair of the U.S.
Civil Rights Commission.
Ron Christie, the vice president of the lobbying group DC Navigators, also a former special assistant to president George W.
Bush.
They both spoke to us from our headquarters in Washington, D.C.
From NPR News, this is News & Notes.
I'm Farai Chideya.
Condoleezza Rice for vice president?
Senator John McCain is putting together his short list of potential running mates, and some Washington insiders would like to see Rice as the number-two on the ticket with McCain.
Some say the Secretary of State would bring diversity and foreign policy know-how to the GOP ticket.
Rice says she's eager to step out of the White House and back into academia, but speculation still looms large.
So what would a McCain-Rice campaign look like, and how would one of the world's most powerful women do as America's second-in-command?
Joining us now is Marcus Mabry, the author of ""Twice as Good: Condoleezza Rice and Her Path to Power,"" and conservative activist Grover Norquist.
He heads Americans for Tax Reform, a grassroots taxpayer advocacy group.
Norquist recently endorsed the idea of Rice as VP.
Gentlemen, welcome.
Hi.
Glad to be with you.
So, Grover, let me start with you.
Sure.
So some of this buzz about Rice as a possible veep candidate stems from her appearance at one of your regular breakfast gatherings for conservatives.
So why was her visit important?
And do you think that - I mean, obviously, you do think that she would be a great veep.
So tell us, first of all, about the visit, and secondly, your opinion about her.
